desc: RAD51C (RAD51 paralog C) encodes a member of the family of RAD51 proteins, which function in homologous recombination (HR)-mediated repair of double-stranded DNA breaks (DSBs). RAD51C is one of five RAD51 paralogs (PMID: 17114795). Although its function is poorly understood, RAD51C is likely involved in resolving Holliday junctions (HJs) at a late stage of homologous recombination (PMID: 17547768). RAD51C is a member of both HR-related complexes, BCDX2 (RAD51B/C/D and XRCC2) and CX3 (RAD51C and XRCC3), which act at different stages in the HR pathway (PMID: 16093548, 23149936). Preclinical studies have shown that deficiency in either complex reduces cellular ability to resolve HJs (PMID: 17114795, 14716019). Biallelic germline mutations of RAD51C are associated with a Fanconi anemia-like disorder (PMID: 20400963). Germline RAD51C mutations confer susceptibility to breast and ovarian cancer (PMID: 20400964, 21616938, 21990120, 22538716), as well as head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (PMID: 24315737). Somatic alterations in RAD51C are infrequently found in cancer (cBioPortal, MSKCC, Nov. 2015). The gene is located at a locus amplified in some tumor but although evidence for elevated expression exists no mechanism implying a role for RAD51C in the progression in these tumors (PMID: 11034067, 11034073).

desc: RAD51C encodes a protein involved in DNA double-strand break repair. Germline mutations of RAD51C are associated with an increased risk of breast and ovarian cancer.
